BARNSTORMERS TO
MEET MONDAY NIGHT
On Monday night, May 5,
the Barnstormers' , Club will
hold a meeting at the home of
Walter B. (Pop) Swindell on
Club Road. All new members
should be present. This consultation will inaugurate a series of monthly meetings which
are being arranged in order to
promote closer contact between
the older Stormers and the
present members of the organization. At these meetings
plans for the future will be
discussed and almuni will be
kept in touch with the movements of the club.

Omicron Delta Kappa held its
semi-annual election at the assembly yesterday. Dr. French, who
was to have delivered the 'address
to the initiates, was unable to be
present, as he was suddenly taken
sick. However, he condescended to
send the manuscript to the Secretary of the Circle, George Gump.
who read the speech.
He commenced by congratulating
the men who had been elected to the
Circle; and then proceeded to give
a brief history of the Fraternity.

Vol. XXXIV, No. 47

"0. D. K'S." NOW

These four men, who have been influential leaders in campus activities were
awarded the laurel leaf, symbol of victory, at yesterday's assembly. They are,
left to right: John Yellot, Robert Kyle, John Heinzerling and George Gettemuller

Soph Banquet Monday,
Jay Netmen Defeat
Univ. of Baltimore Council Men Nominated

THIRD COTILLION AT
SOUTHERN TOMORROW
Tomorrow night the Cotillion Board will present the
Third Cotillion at the Southern Hotel in honor of the West
Point lacrosse team. Previous
to this affair the cadets will
be entertained by the Athletic Association at a banquet.
The dance will last from 9 till
2, and promises to be a fine affair. Percy Glasgow and his
ten-piece plantation band will
furnish the music. The price
of admission will be $2.50 couple and $2 stag. The board has
been losing money on the affairs given this year and is depending upon the support of
the student body at this dance
to help make up the deficit.

JAY TWELVE MEETS
ARMY TOMORROW
Hopkins Stickmen Will Undoubtedly Face A Stronger
Team
SISSON AT GOAL
Black and Blue Team Should
Be In Top Form
An improved Hopkins twelve
and a fighting West Point team
meet at Homewood Field tomorrow afternoon in what promises
to be the Jay's hardest battle to
date. In spite of the St. John'sMaryland game, which will attract
fans, there should be a crowd at
the Hopkins grounds when the
opening whistle blows.
Army Stronger

Army will undoubtedly be
stronger than when they played
Maryland last week. Last week, Waters, an ex-member of the Class
of 1930 at Hopkins, played at goal
in the place of Sisson, who was declared ineligible. Tuesday, however, West Point athletic officials
announced that the ban no Sisson
was lifted and that he would accompany the team to Baltimore. In
addition to this the cadets made
several costly mistakes in the Maryland game and these will undoubtedly be called to their attention and
improved during the week. These
improvements plus the well-known
fact that West Point always has a
fighting team speaks well for the
game tomorrow, from the spectator's point of view.

Striking students at Lincoln Memorial University hauled down the
American flag that flies over their
campus.
"The flag is a symbol of justice,
and we don't want it to float over
the campus of a university where
those qualities have ceased to exist," Clay McCarrol, chairman of
the student body said.
More than 200 of the 425 students at the university struck last
week in protest over summary dismissal of four members of the faculty.

Gridders of the University of
Nebraska have adopted the "no captain" plan for their 1930 team, and
starting September 1, 1931, all athletic teams of the University will
function without captains. The
new plan being adopted has broken
a long-standing tradition of the university. Many other colleges and
universities have eliminated the
captains from all lines of sports.

"College Joes" at the University
of Nebraska recently turned on
"College Josephines" condemning
them as "generally dumb and unsophisticated," strikingly expensive
and appalling in lack of experience.
"In addition to being wild for
dates," the men charged "they try
to play too many men at once and
want to much attention." A majority of men expressed the belief
that more than 25 per cent of the
co-eds are interested in intellectural
attainment while some place the figure at less than 1 per cent.

The University of Paris has fallen heir to the splendid chateau and
grounds in the town of Richelieu,
belonging to the Duke de Richelieu,
descendent of France's famous
cardinal, and well-known in America.
The chateau was built by Cardinal Richelieu on the site of his
birthplace, and was only partially
destroyed during the French Revlution.
It is surrounded by a beautiful
park of more than a thousand acres
which is included in the gift.

The complete reorganization of the Interfraternity Board notes still
further progress. Two of the policies advocated by our predecessor
were a three-week rushing season, and the outlawing of "mud-slinging." These problems are being fully discussed and some action along
these lines may be expected shortly.
However there is another group of these reforms and policies which
have not be followed. This group includes:
1. Active and continued support of the movement for the erection
of a cage on the campus in the near future.
2. Complete abolition of the practice of allowing inexperienced
graduate students to grade quiz papers.

' 3. The naming of the Physics Building after Dr. Henry Augustus
Rowland, world-famous physicist and a member of the original Hopkins faculty.
4. A more careful observation of the honor system in borrowing
library books.
5. A more careful and general use of the University calendar to

avoid conflicts.
One of the changes advocated by our immediate predecessor was
completed when the black list was abolished. There are two other
notable reforms suggested that have not as yet been carried into effect.
These are the admittance of students in the College of Arts and Sciences to a larger number of courses in the School of Business Economics, and a considerable increase in the number of courses offered
to undergraduates.
A year ago the NEWS-LETTER favored either the abolition or enforcement of freshman regulations. After witnessing a season of the
former, we now strongly favor the latter. Freshman regulations to a
limited extent should be re-established. The first-year men should be
compelled to greet all those whom they meet on the campus, to attend
all football games, and to wear some distinctive button or article of
clothing the enforcement of these regulations should be in the hands
of the Student Council, or a committee elected solely for this purpose
by the entire student body. This would eliminate all the unpleasantness connected with a sophomore pep committee. At the same time
this body would be more highly respected, and hence its orders would
be more generally observed.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 2, 1930

Stewart Smith Wins
Thom Cup Contest
On Monday night, April 28, the
Thom Cup Contest was held in Levering Hall. Among those present
were: Mrs. Thom, who donated the
cup, Mr. Wheeler, in charge of the
contest, Dean Berry, and Dr.
French, who presented the cup to
the winner.
The six contestants, all of whom
were presented with the same topic
ten minutes previous to presentation
were: J. Novak, Jr., Burggraff, Anderson, Alpert, Stewart L. Smith
and James Miller. Stewart L.
Smith's delivery was chosen as the
best and he was given the award.
The Thom Cup is presented by
Mrs. Thom each year in memory of
her husband, to the winner of the
contest, the participants of which
are chosen from one of Mr. Wheeler's public speaking classes.
On May 16 the public speaking

THIRD COTILLION AT
SOUTHERN TOMORROW
Tomorrow night the Cotillion Board will present the
Third Cotillion at the Southern Hotel in honor of the West
Point lacrosse team. Previous
to this affair the cadets will
be entertained by the Athletic Association at a banquet.
The dance will last from 9 till
2, and promises to be a fine affair. Percy Glasgow and his
ten-piece plantation band will
furnish the music. The price
of admission will be $2.50 couple and $2 stag. The board has
been losing money on the affairs given this year and is depending upon the support of
the student body at this dance
to help make up the deficit.

JAY TWELVE MEETS
ARMY TOMORROW
Hopkins Stickmen Will Undoubtedly Face A Stronger
Team
SISSON AT GOAL
Black and Blue Team Should
Be In Top Form
An improved Hopkins twelve
and a fighting West Point team
meet at Homewood Field tomorrow afternoon in what promises
to be the Jay's hardest battle to
date. In spite of the St. John'sMaryland game, which will attract
fans, there should be a crowd at
the Hopkins grounds when the
opening whistle blows.
Army Stronger

Army will undoubtedly be
stronger than when they played
Maryland last week. Last week, Waters, an ex-member of the Class
of 1930 at Hopkins, played at goal
in the place of Sisson, who was declared ineligible. Tuesday, however, West Point athletic officials
announced that the ban no Sisson
was lifted and that he would accompany the team to Baltimore. In
addition to this the cadets made
several costly mistakes in the Maryland game and these will undoubtedly be called to their attention and
improved during the week. These
improvements plus the well-known
fact that West Point always has a
fighting team speaks well for the
game tomorrow, from the spectator's point of view.

Striking students at Lincoln Memorial University hauled down the
American flag that flies over their
campus.
"The flag is a symbol of justice,
and we don't want it to float over
the campus of a university where
those qualities have ceased to exist," Clay McCarrol, chairman of
the student body said.
More than 200 of the 425 students at the university struck last
week in protest over summary dismissal of four members of the faculty.

The complete reorganization of the Interfraternity Board notes still
further progress. Two of the policies advocated by our predecessor
were a three-week rushing season, and the outlawing of "mud-slinging." These problems are being fully discussed and some action along
these lines may be expected shortly.
However there is another group of these reforms and policies which
have not be followed. This group includes:
1. Active and continued support of the movement for the erection
of a cage on the campus in the near future.
2. Complete abolition of the practice of allowing inexperienced
graduate students to grade quiz papers.

' 3. The naming of the Physics Building after Dr. Henry Augustus
Rowland, world-famous physicist and a member of the original Hopkins faculty.
4. A more careful observation of the honor system in borrowing
library books.
5. A more careful and general use of the University calendar to

avoid conflicts.
One of the changes advocated by our immediate predecessor was
completed when the black list was abolished. There are two other
notable reforms suggested that have not as yet been carried into effect.
These are the admittance of students in the College of Arts and Sciences to a larger number of courses in the School of Business Economics, and a considerable increase in the number of courses offered
to undergraduates.
A year ago the NEWS-LETTER favored either the abolition or enforcement of freshman regulations. After witnessing a season of the
former, we now strongly favor the latter. Freshman regulations to a
limited extent should be re-established. The first-year men should be
compelled to greet all those whom they meet on the campus, to attend
all football games, and to wear some distinctive button or article of
clothing the enforcement of these regulations should be in the hands
of the Student Council, or a committee elected solely for this purpose
by the entire student body. This would eliminate all the unpleasantness connected with a sophomore pep committee. At the same time
this body would be more highly respected, and hence its orders would
be more generally observed.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 2, 1930

Stewart Smith Wins
Thom Cup Contest
On Monday night, April 28, the
Thom Cup Contest was held in Levering Hall. Among those present
were: Mrs. Thom, who donated the
cup, Mr. Wheeler, in charge of the
contest, Dean Berry, and Dr.
French, who presented the cup to
the winner.
The six contestants, all of whom
were presented with the same topic
ten minutes previous to presentation
were: J. Novak, Jr., Burggraff, Anderson, Alpert, Stewart L. Smith
and James Miller. Stewart L.
Smith's delivery was chosen as the
best and he was given the award.
The Thom Cup is presented by
Mrs. Thom each year in memory of
her husband, to the winner of the
contest, the participants of which
are chosen from one of Mr. Wheeler's public speaking classes.
On May 16 the public speaking
classes will hold their banquet at the
New Howard Hotel, at which after
dinner speeches will be made as part
of the requirements of the course.
Outsiders are welcome, too. The
price of subscription is $2.00.

Economic Growth

In reverse to the ideal of the Middle Ages (unity in the state and
church) we have in modern times,
due to the progress in economic
growth, inventions and communication, grown into "internationalism."

correct a mistake made in its. last
issue which stated that the Senior
Ball would be open to seniors only.

look forward to during the ensuing days.
